title: church, the
comment: The community of faithful believers, of whom Jesus Christ is the head, called out from the world to serve God down the ages. Scripture emphasises that the church is the body of Christ whose members are intended to be filled with the Holy Spirit. Scriptural understanding of the church is corporate, rather than solitary or individual.

children.title: church, OT anticipations of
children.comment: As the people of God, the Christian church is continuous with Israel. The OT provides important anticipations of the church.

children.title: OT terms for the people of God

secondaryrefs.comment: ``children of Abraham'' in the NT refers to those who, like Abraham, put their faith in God

children.title: The saints
children.precomment: The term for ``saints'' means ``set apart for God'', ``made holy'', and is the most frequently used NT term for Christians:

children.title: The assembly
children.precomment: ``assembly'' means ``a community gathered together in response to God's call to serve and worship him''. Its NT equivalents include the synagogue and the church:

children.title: The scope of the OT people of God
Not all Israelites are God's people

primaryrefs.comment: Even within Israel there are believers and unbelievers.

seealsos.comment: Those Israelites who believed were sometimes called ``a remnant''

children.title: The formation of the OT people of God
God's people are formed through God's promises
God's people are chosen and called
God formed a covenant with his people
OT images of the people of God

primaryrefs.comment: This OT image is taken up in the many references to Jesus Christ as the bridegroom and the church as his bride.

seealsos.comment: Israel was sometimes called God's ``firstborn son'' as well as his children

children.title: Requirements of the people of God

primaryrefs.comment: The focus of Israel's commemoration of their redemption was the Passover, which is one of the ceremonies lying behind the Lord's Supper.

children.title: The marks of the people of God
Circumcision as a mark of God's people
church, nature and foundations of
children.comment: The church is the people called by God, who are united by their faith in Christ and by their common life in him. Various descriptions and metaphors emphasise the continuity between the people of God in the OT and NT.

children.title: Emphasising continuity with the OT church
Emphasising God's call and authority in the church
Descriptions applied to the church by outsiders

secondaryrefs.comment: ``the Nazarene sect'' means people belonging to Jesus the ``Nazarene'' (Mt 2:23)

children.title: Descriptions used by Christians
children.precomment: The believers. All these titles are seldom in the singular, emphasising the corporateness of Christian life:

children.title: Other NT descriptions of the church

secondaryrefs.comment: the pillar and foundation of the truth
The church of the firstborn. ``the firstborn'' is plural, referring to Christians as those born again through their union with Christ, who is the firstborn.

children.title: Jesus Christ as the church's foundation-stone
Apostles and prophets as founders of the church
church, unity and fellowship of
children.comment: The church is one in essence, because it is founded on one gospel, united to one Lord and indwelt by one Spirit. Its unity is under constant threat because of the tendency to division that is inherent in fallen humanity, and needs to be continually maintained and actively expressed in fellowship.

seealsos.comment: The great divide threatening the first Christians was between Jew and Gentile, but the church was able to unite the two into one body in Christ.

children.title: The church's unity reflects the unity within the Trinity

primaryrefs.comment: The unity of the church is built around the persons of the Trinity: one Spirit, one Lord, one Father.

children.title: The church's unity is the work of the Trinity
The purpose of the church's unity
The nature of the church's unity

primaryrefs.comment: Emphasis is placed on an inner unity of mind and spirit rather than external uniformity.

children.title: Appeals for unity in the church
The church's unity is expressed in fellowship
Specific actions which express fellowship and unity in the church
Baptism as an expression of unity
Causes of division in the NT church
Warnings against divisions in the church
Acceptable differences in the church
children.precomment: In secondary matters of conscience, Christians are to respect rather than judge each other. These things need not impair the essential unity that is in Christ:

children.title: Necessary divisions in the church
children.precomment: Between the true gospel and heretical alternatives:

children.title: church, leadership of
children.comment: Jesus Christ is the absolute head of the church. He sets leaders in the church to enable the whole church to grow into maturity. Christ's authority in the church is acknowledged more by the church's obedience to God than through any particular form of government.

children.title: Jesus Christ alone is head of the church
The Holy Spirit directs the church
The appointment of leaders in the church

primaryrefs.comment: Judas and Silas were leaders in the Jerusalem church (Ac 15:22).

seealsos.comment: The role of prophets as leaders is distinct from the gift of prophecy, which was in principle available to all

primaryrefs.comment: ``Elder'' and ``overseer'' or ``bishop'' are more or less interchangeable.

children.title: Qualifications for church leadership
children.precomment: The first apostles were witnesses of Jesus Christ's life and resurrection:

children.title: To give direction in church life
To be an example in loving service
To train and appoint other leaders
To exercise discipline in the church
The church's responsibilities to its leaders
To respect and submit to its leaders
The corporate government of the church
In discerning true and false teachings

secondaryrefs.comment: It is unknown whether there were subdivisions of the church in towns such as Corinth
Normally the NT speaks of ``churches'' in an area rather than of a unified regional structure.

children.title: church, purpose and mission of
children.comment: The church is called to praise and glorify God, to establish Jesus Christ's kingdom, and to proclaim the gospel throughout the world.

primaryrefs.comment: ``rulers and authorities in the heavenly realms'' refers to the powers of evil.

children.title: To go into the world in mission
To preach the gospel to the world
Numerical growth among the first Christians
The church is to grow to maturity
Prayers for the growth of the church
Visions of the church's final destiny

primaryrefs.comment: John's vision of the church in glory.

children.title: church, life of
children.comment: The church lives its life in union with Christ and in the power of the Holy Spirit. It is called to mutual love, holy living, and to worship.

children.title: The church lives its life in union with Christ
The church lives in Christ and Christ lives in the church
Believers are united with Christ in baptism
The church lives its life in the power of the Holy Spirit
The church lives in the Spirit, and the Spirit lives in the church

primaryrefs.comment: The indwelling Spirit is identified with the presence of Jesus Christ.

children.title: The Spirit is given to the church
The Spirit endows the church with gifts
As a fellowship of mutual love
As a fellowship of ordinary people
The church as a chosen people
The church as a holy people
The church as a people set apart

primaryrefs.comment: The repeated call to be separate from evil is the practical outworking of the church's sanctification.

children.title: The church as a heavenly people
Praise in the life of the church
Prayer in the life of the church

secondaryrefs.comment: prayer for all, including secular leaders

children.title: Baptism in the life of the church
The Lord's Supper in the life of the church

primaryrefs.comment: The breaking of bread was central to the church's worship and a vital expression of its fellowship.

children.title: Suffering persecution from a hostile world
Sharing in the sufferings of Christ
Suffering as the road to glory
